Say's law is actually correct, and you are only calling it "nonsense" because you clearly haven't understood it (no surprise given your previous 'insights' into economics).
 
 In fact I'm almost certain the only reason you're even claiming it's false is because you read somewhere that Keynes opposed it.
 
 Say's law isn't about specific goods. It doesn't claim there can't be an oversupply of Cherry Cola, its about the impossibility of oversupply in all goods at once, since goods are purchased with other goods, and money only acts as an intermediary.
 
 To look at the current economic situation, there are two ways;
 
 1) Keynes might say there is a general oversupply of goods or a lack of aggregate demand, so markets cannot clear, and the only way to rectify it is by pumping $$$$ into the economy, thus stimulating purchasing.
 
 2) Say would say that there is a specific oversupply of some goods, eg McMansions, overpriced american cars and subprime loans, and that entrepeneurs have misallocated resources into areas where demand was low. He might even recognise the role of the fed's interventions in instigating this misallocation of resources. The correct solution then isn't to try to force or manipulate people into maintaining the status quo allocation of resources, by propping up ailing capitalists, but by letting the market reorganise itself in a manner compatible with consumer demands.

Say's law seems to leave unadressed the possibility of people, in effect, stuffing money under the mattress instead of spending it. In such a system, if goods have been produced, there is necessarily a general over supply - a higher value of goods available than there is demand for them. No matter what goods resources have been allocated to, $10 billion of supply met with $9 billion of demand is in trouble. Certainly it's in even more trouble if 5 of those 10 billion have been allocated to things there is no demand for at all, but the problem still remains even without that.
